senses.sense: (personal) Me and at least one other person; the objective case of we.

examples: Give us a look at your paper.
Give us your wallet!
She's turned the weans against us!
We'll have to throw us food out.
Look at us while you’re speaking to us.
Could you do that for us?

senses.sense: The speakers/writers, or the speaker/writer and at least one other person.
examples: It's not good enough for us teachers.

senses.sense: The state or condition of being usable.
The degree to which an object, device, software application, etc. is easy to use with no specific training.
Easy to use; exhibiting good usability.
The act of using something; use, employment.
The established custom of using language; the ways and contexts in which spoken and written words are used, especially by a certain group of people or in a certain region.
(now archaic) Action towards someone; treatment, especially in negative sense.
(obsolete) One who has the use of anything held in trust for another.
(historical) One of the nonjurors who maintained the "usages", mixed chalices, oblation in prayer of consecration, and prayer for the dead.
The length of time permitted for the payment of a bill of exchange.
The interest paid on a borrowed sum, usury.

examples: The use of torture has been condemned by the United Nations.

senses.sense: (uncountable) The act of consuming alcohol or narcotics.

examples: What's the use of a law that nobody follows?

senses.sense: A function; a purpose for which something may be employed.
examples: This tool has many uses.

senses.sense: Occasion or need to employ; necessity.
examples: I have no further use for these textbooks.

senses.sense: (obsolete, rare) Interest for lent money; premium paid for the use of something; usury.
(archaic) Continued or repeated practice; usage; habit.
(Christianity) A special form of a rite adopted for use in a particular context, often a diocese.
examples: the Sarum, or Canterbury, use; the York use; the Ordinariate use

senses.sense: (forging) A slab of iron welded to the side of a forging, such as a shaft, near the end, and afterward drawn down, by hammering, so as to lengthen the forging.
(transitive) To employ; to apply; to utilize.
examples: Use this knife to slice the bread.
We can use this mathematical formula to solve the problem.

senses.sense: (transitive, often with up) To expend; to consume by employing.
examples: I used the money they allotted me.
We should use up most of the fuel.
She used all the time allotted to complete the test.
You never cared about me; you just used me!

senses.sense: (transitive) To consume (alcohol, drugs, etc), especially regularly.
examples: He uses cocaine. I have never used drugs.

senses.sense: (intransitive) To consume a previously specified substance, especially a drug to which one is addicted.
examples: Richard began experimenting with cocaine last year; now he uses almost every day.

senses.sense: (transitive, with auxiliary "could") To benefit from; to be able to employ or stand.
examples: I could use a drink. My car could use a new coat of paint.

senses.sense: (transitive, with gender pronouns as object) To suggest or request that other people employ a specific set of gender pronouns when referring to the subject.
examples: I use they/them pronouns.

senses.sense: To accustom; to habituate. (Now common only in participial form. Uses the same pronunciation as the noun; see usage notes.)
examples: soldiers who are used to hardships and danger (still common)
to use the soldiers to hardships and danger (now rare)

senses.sense: (intransitive, archaic or literary except in past tense) To habitually do; to be wont to do. (Now chiefly in past-tense forms; see used to.)
examples: I used to get things done.

senses.sense: (dated) To behave toward; to act with regard to; to treat.
examples: to use an animal cruelly

senses.sense: (reflexive, obsolete) To behave, act, comport oneself.
simple past tense and past participle of use
examples: You used me!

senses.sense: (intransitive, auxiliary, defective, only in past tense/participle) To perform habitually; to be accustomed [to doing something].
examples: He used to live here, but moved away last year.
The club used to be frequented by locals; then, after the "incident", it used to get raided by the cops.

senses.sense: That is or has or have been used.
examples: The ground was littered with used syringes left behind by drug abusers.

senses.sense: That has or have previously been owned by someone else.
examples: He bought a used car.
I got used to this weather.

senses.sense: The quality of being used, or having been used.
One who or that which is used.
Having a practical or beneficial use.
In a useful manner; in a way that achieves something
examples: I would rather have it said, "He lived usefully," than, "He died rich."

senses.sense: The quality or degree of being useful.
examples: The usefulness of his latest reorganisation has been disputed.

senses.sense: (NZ) The socialist policy of replacing freehold tenure by a system of perpetual lease from the state, with all land transfer conducted through the state.
Without use or possibility to be used.
examples: This fork's prongs are bent. It's useless now.

senses.sense: Unhelpful, not useful; pointless (of an action).
examples: I think it's useless to keep this discussion going. It's like talking to a brick wall.
I tried my best to make him quit smoking, but my efforts were useless. He now smokes six packs a day.

senses.sense: (pejorative, of a person) Good-for-nothing; not dependable.
examples: Bill never mows the lawn, takes out the trash or anything. He's useless, but I love him anyways.

senses.sense: (colloquial, of a person) Unable to do well at a particular task or thing. Useless is mildly insulting.
examples: My brother is useless at most computer games, but he is an awesome PS2 player.
Why do you keep trying? You're obviously useless at it.

senses.sense: One who uses or makes use of something, a consumer/client or an express or implied licensee (free user) or a trespasser.
A person who uses drugs, especially illegal drugs.
(computing) A person who uses a computer or a computing network, especially a person who has received a user account.
(pejorative) An exploiter, an abuser (a person who "uses" people, that is treats and regards people unfairly, selfishly and/or unethically).
(legal, dated) In land law, meaning either 1. or 2. above or use. Usually in singular form to mean use wherever there is assiduous re-use of precedents and aloof textbooks verbatim.
(legal) A form of equitable ownership peculiar to English law, by which one person enjoys the profits of lands, etc. whose legal title is vested in another in trust.
third-person singular simple present indicative form of use
(colloquial, rare, transitive and intransitive) To usher: to perform the action of an usher: to escort.
Alternative form of uzhe; Clipping of usual.
Alternative form of uzhe; Clipping of usual.
In ancient Egypt, a figurine of a dead person, placed in their tomb to do their work for them in the afterlife.
A person, in a church, cinema etc., who escorts people to their seats.
A male escort at a wedding.
(obsolete) An assistant to a head teacher or schoolteacher; an assistant teacher.
To guide people to their seats.
(figuratively) To precede; to act as a forerunner or herald.
(figuratively, transitive) To lead or guide somewhere.
(obsolete) The act of ushering, or the state of being ushered in.
The office or position of an usher.
simple past tense and past participle of usher
An act of guiding or escorting.
The office or position of an usher.
Any lichen of the genus Usnea.
Of or pertaining to the genus Usnea.
of or relating to usnic acid
(mineral) A white or reddish-pink silicate mineral with chemical formula Na<sub>2</sub>AlSi<sub>3</sub>O<sub>8</sub>(OH).
Any of the genus Ustilago of smut fungi parasitic on grasses.
(obsolete) The act of burning, or the state of being burned.
An act of burning, especially roasting.

examples: The preference of a boy to a girl is a usual occurrence in some parts of China.
It is becoming more usual these days to rear children as bilingual.

senses.sense: The typical state of something, or something that is typical.
(colloquial) A specific good or service (e.g. a drink) that someone typically orders.
examples: I'll just have the usual.

senses.sense: Something that is usual, or employed in the usual way; a norm.
Most of the time; less than always, but more than occasionally.
examples: Except for one or two days a year, he usually walks to work.

senses.sense: The quality or state of being usual.
One who acquires right or title through usucaption.
The acquisition of right or title to an object by means of the passage of time. The common law analogue is adverse possession.
Capable of being transferred by usucaption.
The acquisition of right or title to an object or property by means of the simple passage of time.
One who acquires something by usucaption.
(law) The legal right to use and derive profit or benefit from property that belongs to another person, as long as the property is not damaged.
(law, also figuratively) To use and derive profit or benefit from property that belongs to another person.
(law) Of or pertaining to a usufruct.
(law) A person who holds property, or the use of assets, by usufruct; a fructuary.
A person who loans money to others and charges interest, particularly at an illegal, exorbitant, or unfair rate.

examples: That woman — that usuress — only lent me £20, but expected £50 back after just one week!

senses.sense: To seize power from another, usually by illegitimate means.
To use and assume the coat of arms of another person.
To take the place rightfully belonging to someone or something else.
The wrongful seizure of something by force, especially of sovereignty or other authority.
Trespass onto another's property without permission.
A taking or use without right.
simple past tense and past participle of usurp
examples: The kingdom was usurped by the king's cousin.

senses.sense: The role or status of usurper.
third-person singular simple present indicative form of usurp
(countable) An exorbitant rate of interest, in excess of any legal rates or at least immorally.
(uncountable) The practice of lending money at such rates.
(uncountable, archaic or historical) The practice of lending money at interest.
